Message.Title: In the Bush era Pubs approved of the NSA surveillance program & and dems disapproved
Message.Msg: this whole fake "scandal" is nothing but partisan bs. "Pew is out with the first poll asking the public what it thinks of the NSA phone record surveillance program. Unsurprisingly, the public thinks it's just peachy, by a margin of 56-41. What is surprising, though, is the epic size of the change in partisan attitudes since 2006. Back then, Republicans approved of the (recently revealed) NSA program by 38 points more than Democrats. Now, Republicans disapprove by 12 points more than Democrats. . Basically, when Bush was president, Republicans thought that monitoring telephone traffic was a great idea. Now, when Obama is president, they're not so sure—but Democrats think it's fine and dandy. This is about as remarkable a turnaround as I've seen on any subject in recent years." Bottom line, as long as they're not listening to your calls sans a warrant, no one cares. The phone co. log who you dial and for how long , for billing, service and marketing anyway, assumption Gvt. can get this is assumed

Message.Title: Michael Moore agrees with Glenn Beck. Trump & coulter and the WSJ and obama agree otherwise
Message.Msg: You can draw your own opinions based on the following quotes of a bunch of famous people and news organizations who are wildly split on the NSA snooping issue. 1. Donald Trump. The once and possibly future presidential candidate and reality TV host isn’t a big fan of Edward Snowden, the former CIA analyst who leaked the classified info about the NSA. “To me, he looks like a grandstander,” he told Fox News. 2. Michael Moore. Snowden is “Hero of the Year,” says Moore on Twitter. 3. Ann Coulter. She believes the type of intelligence gathered by the NSA is OK, if it’s done by the right kind of administration. “You need a virtuous man in the presidency, so choose wisely next time, America,” she told Fox News. 4. Jack Welch. The former head of General Electric and former Obama critic on Twitter: “Two Presidents, and multiple split Congress’ all agree we need. Good enough for me.” 5. Glenn Beck. “I think I have just read about the man for which I have waited. Earmarks of a real hero,” Beck said on Twitter about Snowden. 6. The WSJ Editorial Board. The Journal editorial staff argues that the Obama data-mining operation is “legal and necessary” for national security. 7. The New York Times Editorial Board. The editorial says, “The administration has now lost all credibility on this issue” after saying something stronger (before a copy edit). 8. President Barack Obama. “You can’t have 100 percent security and also then have 100 percent privacy and zero inconvenience. We’re going to have to make some choices as a society. There are trade-offs involved,” the president said in defending the program. 9. Senator Dianne Feinstein. “Terrorists will come after us if they can and the only thing we have to deter this is good intelligence,” says Feinstein, who co-chairs the committee that oversees the program for Congress. 10. Senator Saxby Chambliss. “It has proved meritorious because we have gathered significant information on bad guys, but only on bad guys, over the years,”

Message.Msg: Every stinking Terrorist on the planet, certainly any linked to al-Qaeda, has known for YEARS that we have been tracking them, their phones, their conversations, emails, internet activity, addresses, whereabouts and that of most of their relatives and friends! Snowden has not told them one thing of significance that they had not already known... in spades... or put a single American in danger, save of course for the 21st century neo-fascists now running our Government!!! What he did tell us, and the world, is that our Government, under the leadership of our Uber Wunderbar Constitutional Scholar & Moralist, has expanded the tracking and tracing of American citizens, exponentially, on all 310,000,000 of us... and is using all aspects of HIS Governmental power to destroy and undermine his enemies (aka all those who don't agree him and kiss his skinny azzs!)! Indeed, the real TRAITORS are those who leaked, even proclaimed, that Bin Laden was put down by Seal Team Six... an act of Treason and utter Stupidity that got 18 of them (Seals) butchered in a "Revenge" hit by al-Qaeda, along with a dozen other Americans, 30 in total! And those Traitors include Obama, Biden, Clinton, Panetta and others. Real Traitors are those who deliberately denied needed protections to our Embassy staff in Libya and got 4 of them, our Ambassador included, butchered.... and further, never bothered to lift a helping hand to save them!! Clinton, Obama and several Generals are the real traitors!. Real Traitors are also those like Eric Holder, who deliberately lied to a US Court about the 'criminal threat' posed by a FOX journalist, James Rosen, getting him and his family put under Government surveillance for months! Real Traitors sick the IRS on Conservatives! We now have a Government filled with Traitors... certainly at and near the top of many Departments and Agencies!

Message.Msg: White House press secretary Jay Carney said Tuesday that there is an "active investigation" underway following a report that inspector general probes of potential misconduct by State Department personnel were influenced, manipulated or called off improperly by the White House. CBS News, citing an internal State Department Inspector General's memo, reported that senior State Department officials encouraged IG investigators to back off or shutdown investigations of allegations that a State security official in Beirut "engaged in sexual assaults" and that members of former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton's security detail "engaged prostitutes while on official trips in foreign countries." The report also alleges that investigators were told to stop looking into allegations that an ambassador routinely ditched his security detail to solicit sex from prostitutes, and that the ambassador was called to Washington to meet with Undersecretary of State Patrick Kennedy but was allowed to return to his post.
